Award.AwardTitle: Low Dimensional Topology and Real Projective Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The major theme of this project is to develop further the theory of real projective and related geometric structures on manifolds. This is an area where little work has been done and there are many interesting questions. In particular questions of existence, moduli spaces and their compactifications. A second area is to explore the existence of various kinds of surface in 3-manifolds, in particular the virtual Haken question and its relatives. The PI and Tillmann are developing a theory of transversally oriented normal surfaces which we expect to have significant applications. Another project is to develop the theory of Voronoi decompositions (nearest-point neighbor sets for a discretization of a space) beyond the well know setting of Euclidean space to general Riemannian manifolds. Such decompositions are frequently used in computational situations to approximate a continuum by a finite grid. These techniques will enable this to be done in a much more general framework than Euclidean space.

Geometry and topology are playing an increasingly important role in many areas of mathematics and science. In physics ever more sophisticated mathematical ideas from these areas are being used to develop string theory and related areas. In computer science the effective use of graphics requires sophisticated geometry. In biology the construction of evolutionary trees uses techniques from geometry. Projective geometry was born in the Renaissance from the work of the mathematician and artist Gerard Desargues who wanted to accurately depict what he saw on a flat canvas. This led in the nineteenth century to a great mathematical theory. After a period of less activity in the twentieth century projective geometry is again reappearing in a variety of unlikely places. It perhaps offers the possibility for a unified understanding of three dimensional spaces. This is an area with many new problems suitable for training new PhDs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Euclidean geometry is familiar from high school; but is only one kind of geometry. At the turn of the twentieth century Einstein discovered that the geometry of space and time is not this familiar one, but a kind of non-Euclidean geometry discovered by mathematicians 50 years earlier. Today geometric ideas are used in many different areas that, on the face of it, do not seem geometric. The physical layout of the internet, computer graphics, software that recognizes images or writing, spaceflight, astronomy, engineering … the list in endless.

 

Topology is the study of possible spaces. In has many applications. Our universe is an example of a four-dimensional space-time. There are many possible shapes it might be, and topology provides a framework to describe and analyze this. It also provides a way to describe how proteins are knotted. It describes why robotic arms can become unexpectedly entangled. It forms the basis of the string theory that some physicists hope will form a theory of everything.

 

This project develops novel ways of connecting topology and projective geometry. The latter is the geometry of perspective discovered by artists in the renaissance. It provides a way to bring the infinitely far away up close, so it can be precisely analyzed. On a clear day railroad tracks appear to converge to a definite point on the horizon. This is a point in the so-called circle at infinity in the projective plane. Mathematicians discovered that this geometry is closely connected to matrices. These are the arrays of numbers familiar from spreadsheets. Matrices are a cornerstone of mathematics because they describe how many quantities depend on many other quantities. Projective geometry is the geometry of matrices, and thus understanding it has the potential to be applied in almost every part of mathematics, science and engineering.

 

The project has uncovered ways of deforming groups of matrices in expected ways. One the of PhD students involved has discovered new ways for groups of diagonal matrices to be deformed. Diagonal matrices are fundamental to many applications of mathematics, and so it is possible there might be far reaching consequences of this work.
